A. de C.V.|location=[[Mexico]], [[Mexican Federal District|D.F.]]|id=Número 21536 Año LXII|page=18|date=2009-03-23|accessdate=2009-03-23|language=Spanish|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120222093845/http://itecor.v1.myvirtualpaper.com/24032009/2009032401/en/?page=18|archive-date=2012-02-22|dead-url=yes|df=}} |height = {{convert|1.80|m|ftin|abbr=on}}{{cite news|title=Statistics for Professional wrestlers|work=PWI Presents: 2008 Wrestling Almanak and book of facts|publisher=Kappa Publications|id=2008 Edition|pages=66–79}} |weight = {{convert|96|kg|lb|abbr=on}} |birth_date = {{dts|1971|7|1}}{{cite news|last=Flores|first=Manuel|title=Abismo Negro Adiós al rey de marinete|work= SuperLuchas|id=308|location=[[Mexico City]], [[Mexican Federal District|D.F.]]|pages=24–26|date=2009-03-30|language=Spanish}} |birth_place = [[Villahermosa, Tabasco]], [[Mexico]] |death_date = {{death date and age|2009|3|22|1971|7|1}}{{cite web|url=http://www.noroeste.com.mx/publicaciones.php?id=460492&id_seccion=13&fecha=2009-03-23|title=Aparece muerto Abismo Negro, luchador profesional, en un puente de El Rosario|accessdate=2009-03-23|date= 2009-03-23|publisher=www.noroeste.com.mx|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090326041040/http://www.noroeste.com.mx/publicaciones.php?id=460492&id_seccion=13&fecha=2009-03-23| archivedate= 26 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} |death_place = [[El Rosario, Baja California|El Rosario, Sinaloa]], Mexico |spouse = {{marriage|Martha Gonzalez|1994|2009|reason=his death}} |billed = Villahermosa, Tabasco, Mexico |trainer = El Noruego (Don Nerio Soto)

[[Ray Mendoza]] |debut = 1987{{cite web|url=http://www.tabascohoy.com/nota.php?id_nota=172185|title=El Noruego adoptó al Abismo Negro en sus inicios|date=2009-03-25|accessdate=2009-03-28|first=Oscar|last=Rodríguez|publisher=Tabascohoy.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090327025746/http://www.tabascohoy.com/nota.php?id_nota=172185| archivedate= 27 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} }} '''Andrés Alejandro Palomeque González''' (July 1, 1971 – March 22, 2009) was a [[Mexico|Mexican]] [[Lucha libre|Luchador]] ([[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "masked [[Professional wrestling|professional wrestler]]"). He is best known for appearing under the [[ring name|stage name]] '''Abismo Negro''', which is [[Spanish language|Spanish]] for "Black Abyss" or "black hole", in the [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] (AAA) [[professional wrestling promotion|promotion]]. Before appearing under the ring name Abismo Negro, Palomeque worked for five years under the alias "[the] Winners" and before that also wrestled as the characters "Alex Dinamo", "Pequeño Samurai", and "Furor" for short periods. Palomeque owned and operated the ''Gimnasio Abismo Negro'', a wrestling school where individuals were trained to become professional wrestlers. In his professional wrestling career, Palomeque worked for the two most prominent professional wrestling promotions in Mexico: [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL) and AAA. He also worked for the North American–based promotions the [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) and [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling]] (TNA) due to talent exchange programs between AAA and WWF in 1997 and TNA in 2004, as well as making appearances for the [[Michinoku Pro]] and [[Pro Wrestling Noah]] promotions in [[Japan]] On March 22, 2009, Palomeque was found dead in a river near [[El Rosario, Sinaloa|El Rosario]], [[Sinaloa]]; the official cause of death was listed as drowning. On the night before, a wrestler using the Abismo Negro outfit worked an AAA show pretending to be Palomeque; this incident caused the promoter to be barred from promoting shows for two years. Palomeque was inducted into the [[AAA Hall of Fame]] in June 2013. ==Early life== Andrés Alejandro Palomeque González was born July 1, 1971, in [[Villahermosa, Tabasco]], [[Mexico]]. Palomeque started to get interested in professional wrestling at the age of nine when his father, Juan Francisco Palomeque Torres, took him to his first wrestling event. Later the Palomeque Family moved to Poza Rica where a young Palomeque took up [[Pentathlon]] ([[long jump]], [[high jump]], 110 metres [[hurdling|hurdles run]], [[shot put]], 1500 metres run) in school. He and his brother, César Palomeque, had an interest in Martial Arts and trained together for years.{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/especial-abismo-negro.html|title=El material inédito de Abismo Negro|date=2009-05-14|accessdate=2009-07-16|publisher=AAA|language=Spanish|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090525141038/http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/especial-abismo-negro.html|archive-date=2009-05-25|dead-url=yes|df=}} When Palomeque was thirteen years old he began working in a gymnasium where professional wrestlers were trained, initially he paid for the use of the gymnasium by cleaning it after hours. When the family moved back to the Tabasco region he began training under Don Nerio Soto, who worked under the ring name ''El Noruego'' (the [[Norway|Norwegian]]), and his brother Delio Soto to become a luchador, or professional wrestler. Professional wrestlers perform in a non-competitive sport based on simulated fighting with storylines written by creative teams and matches with predetermined results. Don Soto later recollects how he and his family took the young man in and made him part of their family, practically adopting him while he was enrolled in Soto's wrestling school and later as he worked on the local [[Independent circuit|wrestling circuit]]. Palomeque made his professional wrestling debut in 1987, at the age of 16, under the ring name "Alex Dinamo". ==Professional wrestling career== Palomeque received further training from famous Mexican wrestling coaches [[Diablo Velasco]] and [[Ray Mendoza]] before changing his character and ring name to "Pequeño Samurai"—a masked persona patterned after the [[Japan]]ese [[Samurai]] tradition. In 1991, Palomeque began working for [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL; Spanish for "World Wrestling Council"), the biggest wrestling promotion in Mexico at that time. In CMLL, he worked as Furor, another masked ring persona.{{cite web|url=http://superluchas.net/?p=19963|title=Recordando a Abismo Negro: Su vida y legado en los cuadriláteros |accessdate=2009-03-24|date=2009-03-23|publisher=SuperLuchas.net|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090327025114/http://superluchas.net/?p=19963| archivedate= 27 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} While working as Furor, Palomeque won his first ''[[Lucha libre#Luchas de Apuestas|Luchas de apuestas]]'', or "bet match" when he defeated his mentor El Noruego in a match where Noruego's hair and Palomeque's mask was at stake. ===Winners=== In 1992 CMLL head [[Booker (professional wrestling)|writer]] [[Antonio Peña]] left the company to create his own wrestling promotion [[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]] (AAA; Spanish for "Assistance, Consulting and Administration") promotion; Palomeque was one of the many young wrestlers who left CMLL to work for the newly formed AAA. In AAA, his ring personal was changed and he became "Winners" (sometimes written Winner's), a [[Face (professional wrestling)|fan favorite]] character (known as a ''Técnico'' in Lucha Libre) who wore a silver bodysuit and mask. Palomeques work as "Winners" earned him a match on the very first [[Triplemanía I|Triplemanía]] where he teamed with [[Super Caló]] and [[Rafael Herbert Reyes|El Salsero]] to defeat the team of May Flowers, Rudy Reyna, and Baby Sharon in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Trios rules (Relevos Australianos)|Six Man Tag Team match]].{{cite web |url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#i |title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion TripleMania |accessdate= February 19, 2009 |publisher=ProWrestlingHistory.com| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116004505/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html| archivedate= 16 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} The following year at [[Triplemanía II-A]] he teamed up with [[Rey Misterio, Sr.|Rey Misterio]] and [[Rey Mysterio, Jr.|Rey Misterio, Jr.]] to defeat the team known as ''Los Destructores'' (Tony Arce, Vulcano, and Rocco Valente).{{cite web|url= http://slam.canoe.ca/SlamWrestlingInternational/triplemania.html|title=TripleMania: Mexico's answer to WrestleMania|accessdate= 2008-06-16|date=2000-07-05|publisher=SLAM! Sports}} In 1995, Winners participated in a [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Parejas Suicidas|Relevos Suicidas Tag Team match]], in which the losing team members have a match of their own, with the loser of that encounter being forced to unmask. Winners team won the match, keeping him from having to defend his mask in a match. Eight days later at [[Triplemanía III-B]], Winners' mask was on the line in a match against Marabunta; Winners defeated Marabunta in a ''Luchas de Apuestas'', Mask vs. Mask match.{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/tributo-abismo-negro.html|title=Se Nos Adelanto El Rey Del Marinete|first=Miguel G.|last=Fonseca|date=2009-03-24|accessdate=2009-07-16|publisher=AAA|language=Spanish|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327025143/http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/tributo-abismo-negro.html|archive-date=2009-03-27|dead-url=yes|df=}} On June 30, 1995, at [[Triplemanía III-C]], Winners participated in another "mask vs. mask" match, his third in three weeks. This time, Winners was not successful, as he lost to Super Caló and was forced to unmask. The loss of the mask did not hurt Winners' popularity, on the contrary it intensified as the hansome Palomeque became even more popular with the female fans. Despite losing his mask to Super Caló the two continued to work together as a team. On June 15, 1996, Winners and Caló teamed up with Rey Misterio, Jr. and [[Mike Segura|Oro, Jr.]] to defeat the team of Perro Silva, [[Halloween (wrestler)|Halloween]], Kraken, and [[X-Fly|Mosco de la Merced]] at [[Triplemanía IV-B]].{{cite web |url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#iv-b|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion TripleMania|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116004505/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html| archivedate= 16 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} A month later, Winners, Caló, [[Adolfo Tapia|La Parka]] and El Mexicano defeated [[Jerry Estrada]], [[Fishman (wrestler)|Fishman]], [[Villano IV]], and May Flowers in one of the featured matches of [[Triplemanía IV-C]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#iv-c|title= Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion TripleMania|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116004505/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html| archivedate= 16 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} ===Abismo Negro=== In January 1997, Palomeque's character was changed from that of the quintessential heroic ladies' man known as "Winners", to that of a cheating [[Heel (professional wrestling)|villain]] (referred to as a ''Rudo'') known as "Abismo Negro". Part of his new routine as Abismo Negro was a flamethrower display, created by using a lighter and an [[Aerosol spray]] can. Palomeque would regularly use this during his entrance and on occasion during a match as when he worked as "Abismo Negro" character. As part of his Rudo act Palomeque began using the ''Marinete'' — a wrestling move known as a [[Piledriver (professional wrestling)|Piledriver]] where he simulates driving the top of his opponents' head into the mat — the Marinete is "banned" Mexican wrestling, which means that it can lead to a disqualification if used during the match. The Marinete became such a signature move for the Abismo Negro character that he earned the nickname ''El Rey del Martinete'' (The King of the Piledriver). He made his debut as Abismo Negro on January 10, 1997, in an [[Professional wrestling tag team match types#Multiple man teamed matches|Eight Man Tag Team match]].{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/abismo-debut.html|title=El Debut de Abismo Negro|accessdate=2009-03-28|date=2009-03-26|publisher=[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración]]|language=Spanish|archive-url=https://archive.is/20090329115337/http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/abismo-debut.html|archive-date=2009-03-29|dead-url=yes|df=}} Shortly after his debut as Abismo Negro, he made his [[World Wrestling Entertainment|World Wrestling Federation]] (WWF) debut on the January 19, 1997, episode of the [[WWE Free for All|WWF Free For All]] [[pay-per-view]] [[List of WWE pay-per-view events|event]] pre–show before the [[Royal Rumble (1997)|1997 Royal Rumble]]. On the telecast, Negro teamed with [[Heavy Metal (wrestler)|Heavy Metal]] and [[Super Crazy|Histeria]] in a losing effort against the team of [[Octagón]], [[Blue Demon, Jr.]], and [[Tinieblas, Jr.]] in a six-man tag team match.{{cite web|url=http://www.f4wonline.com/content/view/8736/| title=This is one bad week for the wrestling business|accessdate=2009-07-15|publisher=Wrestling Observer / Figure Four Online}}{{cite news|last=Martin|first=Fin|title=Back on Top (Royal Rumble 1997)|work =Power Slam Magazine|id=32|location= England|pages=12–15|date=March 1997}}{{cite web|url= http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/wweppv/royalrumble97.html |title=Royal Rumble 1997 Results|accessdate=2008-02-04| publisher=Online World of Wrestling| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20080217030825/http://www.onlineworldofwrestling.com/results/wweppv/royalrumble97.html| archivedate= 17 February 2008 | deadurl= no}} This match was one of the early results of a working relationship between the WWF and AAA that had been created in late 1996. The relationship saw Negro make an appearance in January against [[Perro Aguayo, Jr.]] and two appearances on the WWF's primary television program ''[[WWE Raw|Monday Night Raw]]'' in March 1997. During his appearances in March, Negro was announced as being part of [[Los Vipers]], a recently created alliance of wrestlers. After March, Negro did not make any more appearances for the WWF. In AAA, [[Cibernético]] formed ''[[Los Vipers]]'' with Negro along with [[Psicosis II|Psicosis (II)]], Mosco De La Merced, Maniaco and Histeria. Histeria was replaced a few weeks later by [[Histeria (wrestler)|Histeria II]]. In 1998, Negro acquired a "mascot": a [[Midget professional wrestling|midget wrestler]] called [[Mini Abismo Negro]]. Abismo, Mini Abismo, and new Vipers member [[Electroshock (wrestler)|Electroshock]] were defeated by Octagón, his mascot [[Octagóncito (AAA)|Octagóncito]], and Pentagón in a six-man tag team match at [[Triplemanía]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#vi|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion TripleMania|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116004505/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html| archivedate= 16 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} Los Vipers engaged in several scripted rivalries with other AAA groups, such as the group of masked wrestlers dressed as clowns known as Los Payasos. They also had a long-running rivalry with Los Vatos Locos—consisting of Espiritu, Picudo, [[Nygma (wrestler)|Nygma]], May Flowers, and Silver Cat during the rivalry—over the [[Mexican National Atómicos Championship]]. Los Vipers won the Atómicos titles from Los Vatos on several occasions, but Negro was not part of the teams that won. Palomeque wrestling as Abismo Negro did capture a title of his own when he defeated Pentagón on May 19, 1998, to win the [[Mexican National Middleweight Championship]], a title he held until January 1999.{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will| title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|chapter=MEXICO: National Middleweight Championship|page=392 |year=2000 |isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} In 1999, Los Vipers split into two factions, with Abismo Negro leading a splinter group called ''Los Vipers Extreme'' consisting of Electroshock, Pentagón, [[Cima (wrestler)|Shiima]], [[Dark Cuervo|El Cuervo]] and Mini Abismo Negro while Cibernético created a group called ''Los Vipers Primera Clase'' (First Class Vipers). After less than two months, the [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Angle|angle]] was dropped and Los Vipers reunited. Not long after Los Vipers reunited, Cibernético formed a group called Lucha Libre Latina (LLL), a group intent on taking over AAA that was inspired by [[World Championship Wrestling]]'s [[New World Order (professional wrestling)|New World Order]]. Los Vipers became a subgroup within LLL, and Negro assumed leadership of Los Vipers. On May 2, 1999, Negro and Electroshock teamed up to defeat [[Perro Aguayo]] and Perro Aguayo, Jr. to win the [[Mexican National Tag Team Championship]]. Los Vipers held the tag team title for four months before losing it to the team of Haytor and the Panther.{{cite book|author=Royal Duncan and Gary Will|chapter=MEXICO: National Tag Team Titles |pages=396–397|title=Wrestling Title Histories|publisher=Archeus Communications|year=2000|isbn=0-9698161-5-4}} In 2000, Palomeque participated in a AAA tour of [[Japan]] and competed at [[Triplemanía VIII]], where he was on the losing side of an eight-man tag team match main event; Negro teamed with Cibernetico, [[Nobuhiko Oshima|Shiima Nobunaga]] and Electro Shock against Octagón, [[Jushin Thunder Liger]], [[Latin Lover (wrestler)|Latin Lover]] and Cuije.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#viii|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion TripleMania|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116004505/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html| archivedate= 16 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} While touring with AAA, Palomeuqe also made an appearance at [[Michinoku Pro]]'s April 9 Sumo Hall card, where he defeated [[Oriental (wrestler)|Oriental]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/lucha/mich/michcard.html#0400|title=Michinoku Pro Shows|accessdate=2009-03-03|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090227041853/http://prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/japan/lucha/mich/michcard.html| archivedate= 27 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} On May 7, Abismo Negro and Electroshock regained the Mexican National Tag Team title by defeating Haytor and the Panther but only held on to the title for two months before losing it to [[Héctor Garza]] and Perro Aguayo, Jr. Negro became one of the driving forces in LLL's feud with AAA owner Antonio Peña and his AAA loyalists. Over the years, Negro feuded with the top técnicos of AAA such as [[La Parka II|La Parka, Jr.]], Octagón and [[Latin Lover (wrestler)|Latin Lover]]. Negro's position as one of AAA's top workers was cemented on March 5, 2000, when he competed in AAA's annual [[Rey de Reyes (2000)|Rey de Reyes]] tournament. In the opening round, he defeated [[Dos Caras]], Killer and Psicosis II and in the finals, he defeated [[El Alebrije (wrestler)|El Alebrije]], [[Charly Manson]] and Cibernético to win the 2000 Rey de Reyes tournament.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2000|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes 2000|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301173345/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2000|archivedate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|df=}} Negro's status as a main eventer caused storyline problems between LLL's leader Cibernético and Abismo Negro, leading to a series of matches between the two to see who should lead Los Vipers. On September 29, 2000, Negro defeated Cibernético in a one on one match at [[Verano de Escandalo (2000)]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/verano.html#2000|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Verano de Escandalo|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090226191723/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/verano.html| archivedate= 26 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} When the two faced off in a [[Professional wrestling match types#Cages|steel cage match]] at [[Guerra de Titanes (2000)]], the match ended without a winner, after which the rivalry between the leader and the deputy leader was put on the back burner.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/guerra.html#2000|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Guerra de Titanes|accessdate=2009-02-19| publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090107055509/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/guerra.html| archivedate= 7 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} In 2001, Negro almost won Rey de Reyes again, but La Parka, Jr. defeated him in the finals.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2001|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes 2001|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301173345/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2001|archivedate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|df=}} His string of losses continued at [[Triplemanía IX]], where the LLL team of Abismo Negro, Cibernético, Electroshock and Mascara Maligna lost to Mascara Sagrada, El Alebrije, Octagón and La Parka, Jr. when Negro was forced to submit.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#ix|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion TripleMania|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116004505/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html| archivedate= 16 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} In 2000 Abismo Negro won the hair of the Panther in ''Lucha del reves'' match, a contest where two masked wrestlers put their hair on the line instead of their mask. On September 7, 2001 Abismo Negro won another Lucha del reves match, defeating [[El Alebrije (wrestler)|El Alebrije]]. In December 2002, Negro and Mini Abismo Negro made it to the finals of a tournament to crown the first ever [[AAA Mascot Tag Team Championship|AAA Mascot Tag Team Champions]] but lost to Mascara Sagrada and [[Mascarita Sagrada]]. Negro qualified for the [[Rey de Reyes (2003)]] final, but La Parka, Jr. once again defeated him.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2003|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes Tournament|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301173345/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2003|archivedate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|df=}} In 2004, LLL was phased out in favor of a new super group known as ''[[Foreign Legion (wrestling)|La Legión Extranjera]]'' or the Foreign Legion in English, which meant that Los Vipers now regularly teamed with foreign wrestlers, especially [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling|NWA-TNA]] performers such as [[Abyss (wrestler)|Abyss]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html#xii|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion TripleMania|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090116004505/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/triple.html| archivedate= 16 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} ===Total Nonstop Action Wrestling=== In 2004, TNA and AAA began a working relationship that saw TNA wrestlers work in Mexico and AAA wrestlers make several appearances on TNA's [[Total Nonstop Action Wrestling#Former programming|weekly]] [[pay-per-view]]s. Managed by AAA owner Antonio Peña, Palomeque, working as Abismo Negro, along with [[Héctor Garza]], [[Juventud Guerrera]], [[Mr. Águila]], and later Heavy Metal, worked for TNA as [[Team Mexico|Team AAA]] in the [[TNA 2004 America's X Cup Tournament]]. The team made their debut on January 28, 2004, at TNA Weekly pay-per-view event #78, defeating the team of [[Eric Young (wrestler)|Eric Young]], [[Shark Boy]], [[Matt Stryker]] and [[Chad Collyer]].{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/news2004/1075385609.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV results - 1/28/04 (Don Callis, Mikey Whipwreck and more)|accessdate=2009-07-16|date=2004-01-29|publisher=WrestleView}} In the following weeks, Negro and Team AAA won against [[Elix Skipper]], the team of [[Jerry Lynn]] and [[Sonjay Dutt]] and finally all of [[Team USA (professional wrestling)|Team USA]] in a 4 on 4 match to claim the Americas X Cup.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/nwatna/nwatna2004/1076562177.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV Results - 2/11/04 (AAA wins the America's X Cup + more)|last=Martin| first=Adam|accessdate=2009-07-15|date=2004-02-12|publisher=WrestleView}} Four weeks later Team AAA successfully defended the X Cup against [[Team Canada (TNA)|Team Canada]], as Abismo Negro and Juventud Guerrera defeated the team of [[Teddy Hart]] and [[Jack Evans (wrestler)|Jack Evans]] to tie the score between the two teams, allowing for a final four-on-four elimination match that Team AAA won.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/nwatna/nwatna2004/1078985242.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV Results - 3/10/04 (Team AAA retains the America's X Cup)|accessdate=2009-07-15|date=2004-03-11|last=Martin|first=Adam|publisher=WrestleView}} Abismo Negro and the rest of Team AAA returned for the [[TNA 2004 World X Cup Tournament|2004 World X Cup Tournament]] where they now competed as "Team Mexico". Abismo Negro remained undefeated until April 7, 2004, when his team lost to James Mason and Jason Allgood in one of the first matches of the World X Cup Tournament. Later in the night, Team Mexico defeated [[Team Britain|Team UK]] to even the score.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/nwatna/nwatna2004/1081398048.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV Results - 4/7/04 - (Team AAA wins, New NWA Tag Champs)|accessdate=2009-07-15|date=2004-04-08|last=Martin|first=Adam| publisher=WrestleView}} The World Cup saw Team Mexico lose to Team USA,{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/nwatna/nwatna2004/1083256634.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV Results - 4/28/04 (Styles defends NWA World Title and more)|last=Martin| first=Adam|accessdate=2009-07-15|date=2004-04-29|publisher=WrestleView}} Team Canada (Eric Young and [[Robert Roode|Bobby Roode]]),{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/nwatna/nwatna2004/1084453597.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV Results - 5/12/04 (A.J. Styles retains, Fox Sports Net, more)|last=Martin|first=Adam|accessdate=2009-07-15|date=2004-05-13|publisher= WrestlingView}} and Team Japan ([[Ryuji Hijikata]] and Mitsu Hirai, Jr.).{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/nwatna/nwatna2004/1085058171.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV Results - 5/19/04 (NEW NWA World Champion, much more)|last= Martin|first=Adam|accessdate=2009-07-15|date=2004-05-20|publisher=WrestleView}} Team Mexico tied in points with Team USA and Team Canada, which meant that a representative of each team met in an [[Ultimate X match]] to determine the winner of the tournament. Héctor Garza represented Mexico, but in the end Team USA's [[Chris Sabin]] won the match and the tournament.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/results/nwatna/nwatna2004/1085631026.shtml|title=Full NWA TNA PPV Results - 5/26/04 (Team NWA captures the X Cup and more)|last=Martin|first=Adam|accessdate=2009-07-15|date=2004-05-27|publisher=WrestleView}} ===Return to AAA=== After the World X Cup tournament ended, Negro returned to AAA full-time taking full charge of Los Vipers. In early 2005, he was once again involved in the final match of that year's [[Rey de Reyes (2005)|Rey de Reyes]], but La Parka, Jr. defeated him for the third time.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2005|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes Tournament|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301173345/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2005|archivedate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|df=}} AAA hinted at a possible técnico [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#Turn|turn]] when Negro, along with Psicosis and [[Mini Psicosis]], attacked Cibernético. The two faced off in a cage match, won by Cibernético, but they eventually reconciled their differences once more. At some point after 2005 Abismo Negro won the hair of [[Stuka, Jr.]] in a Lucha del reves match. Despite rumors that he was jumping to [[Consejo Mundial de Lucha Libre]] (CMLL), Negro remained in AAA and was sent on a tour with [[Pro Wrestling Noah]] in the spring of 2006. Later in the year, he finally turned técnico and began a sustained storyline with Cibernético and his group [[La Secta (wrestling)#La Secta Cibernetica|La Secta Cibernetica]].{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/guerra.html#2005|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Guerra de Titanes|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090107055509/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/guerra.html| archivedate= 7 January 2009 | deadurl= no}} The on again, off again storyline with Cibernético was put on hold when Cibernético suffered a severe knee injury in late 2006. At some point during 2006, Los Vipers left La Legión due to their "Anti-Mexican" philosophy and began fighting La Legión and La Legión's imported wrestlers. At [[Verano de Escandalo (2006)]], Negro, Charly Manson, Electroshock and Histeria lost to Team TNA ([[Homicide (wrestler)|Homicide]], [[Low Ki]], [[Samoa Joe]] and [[A.J. Styles]]).{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/verano.html#2006|title= Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Verano de Escandalo|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090226191723/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/verano.html| archivedate= 26 February 2009 | deadurl= no}} ===Black Abyss=== In late 2007, AAA created a ring persona for a new wrestler called [[Black Abyss]]; the gimmick featured the same mask and attire as Negro and used a similar wrestling style to Negro as well. Initially, it was believed that this was done because there were rumors of him jumping to CMLL or to cover several [[Glossary of professional wrestling terms#No-show|no-shows]]. In 2008, Negro's "almost winning" streak at [[Rey de Reyes (2008)|Rey de Reyes]] continued as he lost in the final to [[El Zorro (wrestler)|El Zorro]]. Black Abyss made sure Negro did not win but interfering on Zorro's behalf during the match, furthering the storyline between the two.{{cite web|url=http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2008|title=Asistencia Asesoria y Administracion Rey de Reyes Tournament|accessdate=2009-02-19|publisher=Pro Wrestling History|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301173345/http://www.prowrestlinghistory.com/supercards/mexico/aaa/rey.html#2008|archivedate=2009-03-01|deadurl=yes|df=}} During the fall of 2008, AAA pushed the storyline further by having Black Abyss "injure" Negro with his own trademark move the "Martinete". Abismo Negro was scheduled to take part in [[Triplemanía XVI]] in a match where he would face Los Vipers (Psicosis, Histeria, Black Abyss and [[Mr. Niebla]]) in a cage match, but in the weeks leading up to the show Abismo Negro suffered an injury and the match had to be cancelled, AAA used the attack at Rey de Reyes as a storyline explanation of why the match did not take place.{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/segunda-triplemania-sin-abismo-negro.html|title=La segunda TripleMania Sin Abismo Negro|date=2009-06-09|accessdate=2009-07-16|publisher=AAA|language=Spanish}}{{Dead link|date=August 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} At the 2008 [[Guerra de Titanes (2008)|Guerra de Titanes]], Negro returned to challenge Los Vipers' Revolution and specifically Black Abyss.{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/abismo-negro-reaparece-en-xalapa.html|title=En Xalapa y Evento Grabado para la TV Reaparece Abismo Negro|accessdate=2009-03-04|language=Spanish|publisher=luchalibreAAA.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327040606/http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/abismo-negro-reaparece-en-xalapa.html|archivedate=2009-03-27|deadurl=yes|df=}} Subsequently, the storyline between Negro and Black Abyss seemed to be building to a Luchas de Apuestas fight between the two, with their masks on the line.{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/rivalidad-abismo-negro-black-abyss.html|title=En Cuautla Abismo Negro VS. Black Abyss|accessdate=2009-03-04|language=Spanish|publisher=luchalibreAAA.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090228174932/http://luchalibreaaa.com/rivalidad-abismo-negro-black-abyss.html|archivedate=2009-02-28|deadurl=yes|df=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/abismo-negro-reaparece.html|title=Abismo Negro nuevamente sufre martinete|accessdate=2009-03-04|language=Spanish|publisher=luchalibreAAA.com|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090327040625/http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/abismo-negro-reaparece.html|archivedate=2009-03-27|deadurl=yes|df=}} Both Abismo and Black Abyss were booked in the same four-way elimination match qualifier at the [[Rey de Reyes (2009)]] event. Negro was able to eliminate Black Abyss from the match but was in turn eliminated by Latin Lover.{{cite web|url=http://superluchas.net/?p=19179|title=Resultados de Rey de Reyes-AAA (16 marzo 2008) Electroshock nuevo Rey de Reyes. Juventud Guerrera y Marco Corleone las sorpresas. Wagner se presenta en AAA para retar al Mesías.|accessdate=2009-03-16|date =2009-03-15|publisher=SuperLucha.net|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090317070418/http://superluchas.net/?p=19179| archivedate= 17 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} Black Abyss still competed under the Black Abyss name, still as a rudo, but seemingly only a couple times on TV since then. Black Abyss has stated his wishes to continue with the character to honor the memory of Abismo Negro, but AAA didn't shown a lot of interest in using it on TV. In October 2010 it was reported that Black Abyss had left AAA.{{cite web|url=http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1287777397 |title=Viva La Raza! Lucha Weekly |last=Boutwell |first=Josh |date=2010-10-22 |accessdate=2010-10-23 |work=WrestleView |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101024184613/http://www.wrestleview.com/viewnews.php?id=1287777397 |archivedate=2010-10-24 }} ===Abismo Negro II=== On September 27, 2011, AAA announced the start of a competition to find a new Abismo Negro.{{cite web|url=http://superluchas.net/2011/09/28/doce-participantes%E2%80%A6-un-nuevo-abismo-negro/|title=Doce participantes... Un nuevo Abismo Negro|author=Mexicool, Rey|date=2011-09-28|accessdate=2011-09-28|publisher=''SuperLuchas'' Magazine|language=Spanish}} In the end no one was chosen to take over the Abismo Negro character. ==Personal life== Palomeque was married to a woman named Martha for 15 years and the couple had four children, two girls and two boys. Palomeque's wife has been suffering from [[breast cancer]] for a number of years.{{cite web|url= http://www.tabascohoy.com/nota.php?id_nota=172497|title=Expediente Abismo Negro: Habla la ex amante|author=Redacción|publisher= TabascoHoy.com|date=2009-04-01|accessdate=2009-04-02|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090403191839/http://www.tabascohoy.com/nota.php?id_nota=172497| archivedate= 3 April 2009 | deadurl= no}} He often appeared on the morning television program ''Vida TV'', in full wrestling gear and persona, billed as Abismo Negro. He usually appeared as a kind of judge for talent contests on the show earning him the nickname ''Fiscal De Hierro de la Televisión'' (the Iron Judge of Television). Palomeque owned and operated "Gimnasio Abismo Negro" where he taught both professional wrestling and physical fitness. Graduates of Abismo Negro's wrestling school include Independent wrestling workers [[El Intocable]], Extassis and Mini Cibernético as well as AAA workers [[Sexy Star]] and [[Aero Star]]. Abismo Negro is a playable character in AAA's first ever [[video game]], ''[[AAA El Videojuego]]''.{{cite web|url= http://www.gamespot.com/xbox360/sports/aaaelvideojuego/news.html?sid=6212457&om_act=convert&om_clk=newsfeatures&tag=newsfeatures;| title=AAA Lucha Libre headed for US|date=2009-06-24|accessdate=2009-06-27|publisher=[[GameSpot]]|first=Brendan|last=Sinclair}} The Abismo Negro character was one of the first characters used to promote the game and show the quality of the graphic rendering.{{cite web|url=http://www.luchalibreaaa.com/video-juego-triple-a.html?next=9|title=La llegada del videojuego de Triple A|date=2009-03-09|accessdate=2009-07-16|publisher=[[Asistencia Asesoría y Administración|AAA]]|language=Spanish}}{{Dead link|date=September 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} ==Death== Palomeque was found dead on March 22, 2009. His body was found in a river near the town of [[El Rosario, Baja California|El Rosario]], [[Sinaloa]]. According to a bus driver who was transporting Palomeque and other passengers to [[Mexico City]] on Friday night March 20, Palomeque became agitated, panicked and demanded to be let off the bus despite it being 1:30 in the morning. A [[text message]] he sent to his wife after leaving the bus confirms that Palomeque found himself lost on the dark hillside. After receiving the text message, his wife contacted local wrestling promoter Vicente Martinez, who organized a search party. On the morning of March 22, Palomeque was found floating face down in the river. Afterwards, medical expert Jesús Enrique Castro López stated that such an [[anxiety attack]] could be [[Anabolic steroid|steroid]] related, but Palomeque's alleged steroid abuse has not been confirmed. An autopsy was carried out on March 23, which determined that the cause of death was drowning, and no further investigation into the death is planned.{{cite web|url=http://www.tabascohoy.com/nota.php?id_nota=172134|title=Abismo negro ¡Murió ahogado!|accessdate=2009-03-24|date=2009-03-24|publisher=Tabasco Hoy|language= Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090326235037/http://www.tabascohoy.com/nota.php?id_nota=172134| archivedate= 26 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} A memorial was held in Mexico City on March 24 for friends and family of Palomeque, many of whom showed up without their masks on, to keep the focus of the event on Palomeque.{{cite web|url=http://superluchas.net/?p=20141|title= Hoy será velado Abismo Negro en la colonia San Angel de la Ciudad de México|accessdate=2009-03-24|date=2009-03-24|publisher= SuperLuchas.net|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090327025329/http://superluchas.net/?p=20141| archivedate= 27 March 2009 | deadurl= no}} His body was subsequently [[cremation|cremated]], with the ashes taken to Villahermosa to be buried. On Saturday March 21, while Palomeque was either lost in the hills or already dead, someone worked as Abismo Negro on an AAA show in [[Cancun]]. In the past, the wrestler known as Black Abyss had worked as Abismo Negro when Palomeque failed to show, but this time Black Abyss was not the man behind the mask, as he was on the opposing team that night. Following the discovery of Palomeque's body, the deception in Cancun received national coverage in Mexico and the local promoter responsible for the show, Renán Martínez, was suspended for two years by the Benito Júarez Boxing and Wrestling commission.{{cite web|url=http://superluchas.net/?p=21047|title=¿Veto por dos años, al promotor y a la AAA por el aparente fraude de Abismo Negro en Cancún?|first=Jorge Ocampo| last=Alcazar|publisher=SuperLuchas.net|date=2009-03-31|accessdate=2009-04-02|language=Spanish| archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20090406105730/http://superluchas.net/?p=21047| archivedate= 6 April 2009 | deadurl= no}}{{cite web|url=http://www.univision.com/content/content.jhtml?chid=4&schid=1037&secid=0&cid=1893827|title=Suplantaron a 'Abismo' el día que murió: Comisión de box y lucha investiga|author=Notimex|publisher=Univision|date=2009-04-02|accessdate=2009-04-02|language=Spanish|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090406052415/http://www.univision.com/content/content.jhtml?chid=4&schid=1037&secid=0&cid=1893827|archivedate=6 April 2009|deadurl=yes|df=}} On October 26, 2009 AAA held the ''Torneo Abismo Negro'' in honor of Palomeque, the tournament was a 7-man [[Gauntlet for the Gold|gauntlet]]-style match and included a mix of five AAA veterans and two Abismo Negro students. The participants were [[Dark Cuervo|Cuervo]], Black Abyss, [[Gato Eveready]], Kempo Dragon, [[Joe Lider]], [[Extreme Tiger]] and Relámpago. Relámpago, Abismo Negro's last student to turn professional, won the match after 48 minutes. The event was not televised and did not become an annual event.{{cite news|last=Echeagaray|first=Jorge|title=Se realizó el torneo "Abismo Negro"|work=SuperLuchas|id=318|location=[[Mexico City]], [[Mexican Federal District|D.F.]]|pages=6–7|date=2009-06-08|language=Spanish}} During [[Triplemania XVII]] there was a moment of silence in memory of Abismo Negro, Antonio Peña and [[Mitsuharu Misawa]] (Misawa had died the night before).{{cite web|url= Hijo del Santo salva a AAA - Nuevo Mega Campeón: Dr. Wagner Jr. - Xtreme Tiger nuevo Campeón Crucero AAA|author=Jose Miguel|date=2009-06-13|accessdate=2009-06-14|publisher=SuperLuchas {{About|the product testing method|the medical condition|Accelerated aging disease}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2013}} '''Accelerated aging''' is testing that uses aggravated conditions of heat, humidity, oxygen, sunlight, vibration, etc. to speed up the normal aging processes of items. It is used to help determine the long-term effects of expected levels of stress within a shorter time, usually in a laboratory by controlled [[Technical standard|standard]] [[test method]]s. It is used to estimate the useful lifespan of a product or its [[shelf life]] when actual lifespan data is unavailable. This occurs with products that have not existed long enough to have gone through their useful lifespan: for example, a new type of car engine or a new polymer for replacement joints.
[[Physical test]]ing or [[chemical test]]ing is carried out by subjecting the product to * representative levels of stress for long time periods, * unusually high levels of stress used to accelerate the effects of natural aging, or * levels of stress that intentionally force failures (for further analysis). Mechanical parts are run at very high speed, far in excess of what they would receive in normal usage. Polymers are often kept at elevated temperatures, in order to accelerate chemical breakdown. [[Environmental chamber]]s are often used.
Also, the device or material under test can be exposed to rapid (but controlled) changes in temperature, humidity, pressure, strain, etc. For example, cycles of heat and cold can simulate the effect of day and night for a few hours or minutes.
==Library and archival preservation science== Accelerated aging is also used in library and archival preservation science. In this context, a material, usually paper, is subjected to extreme conditions in an effort to speed up the natural aging process. Usually, the extreme conditions consist of elevated temperature, but tests making use of concentrated pollutants or intense light also exist.<ref name="Porck">{{cite web|url=http://www.ica.org/download.php?id%3D604 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2014-11-19 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141129054703/http://www.ica.org/download.php?id=604 |archivedate=29 November 2014 |df=dmy }}, Porck, H. J. (2000). ''Rate of paper degradation: The predictive value of artificial aging tests.'' Amsterdam: European Commission on Preservation and Access.</ref> These tests may be used for several purposes.
* ''To predict the long-term effects of particular conservation treatments. '' In such a test, treated and untreated papers are both subjected to a single set of fixed, standardized conditions. The two are then compared in an effort to determine whether the treatment has a positive or negative effect on the lifespan of the paper.<ref name="Porck"/> * ''To study the basic processes of paper decay. '' In such a test, the purpose is not to predict a particular outcome for a specific type of paper, but rather to gain a greater understanding of the chemical mechanisms of decay.<ref name="Porck"/> * ''To predict the lifespan of a particular type of paper. '' In such a test, paper samples are generally subjected to several elevated temperatures and a constant level of relative humidity equivalent to the relative humidity in which they would be stored. The researcher then measures a relevant quality of the samples, such as folding endurance, at each temperature. This allows the researcher to determine how many days at each temperature it takes for a particular level of degradation to be reached. From the data collected, the researcher extrapolates the rate at which the samples might decay at lower temperatures, such as those at which the paper would be stored under normal conditions. In theory, this allows the researcher to predict the lifespan of the paper. This test is based on the [[Arrhenius equation]]. This type of test is, however, a subject of frequent criticism.<ref name="Porck"/>
There is no single recommended set of conditions at which these tests should be performed. In fact, temperatures from 22 to 160 degrees Celsius, relative humidities from 1% to 100%, and test durations from one hour to 180 days have all been used.<ref name="Porck"/> ISO 5630-3 recommends accelerated aging at 80 degrees Celsius and 65% relative humidity<ref name="Bansa 1992">Bansa, H. (1992). Accelerated aging tests in conservation research: Some ideas for a future method. ''Restaurator 13.3'', 114-137.</ref> when using a fixed set of conditions.
Besides variations in the conditions to which the papers are subjected, there are also multiple ways in which the test can be set up. For instance, rather than simply placing single sheets in a climate controlled chamber, the Library of Congress recommends sealing samples in an air-tight glass tube and aging the papers in stacks, which more closely resembles the way in which they are likely to age under normal circumstances, rather than in single sheets.<ref name="LOC 2006">{{cite web|url=https://www.loc.gov/preserv/acceltest.html |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2009-08-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090727062407/http://www.loc.gov/preserv/acceltest.html |archivedate=27 July 2009 |df=dmy }}, Library of Congress (2006). Accelerated aging of paper: A new test. ''The Library of Congress: Preservation''. Retrieved 8 August 2009.</ref>
===History=== The technique of artificially accelerating the deterioration of paper through heat was known by 1899, when it was described by W. Herzberg.<ref name="Porck"/> Accelerated aging was further refined during the 1920s, with tests using sunlight and elevated temperatures being used to rank the permanence of various papers in the United States and Sweden. In 1929, a frequently used method in which 72 hours at 100 degrees Celsius is considered equivalent to 18–25 years of natural aging was established by R. H. Rasch.<ref name="Porck"/>
In the 1950s, researchers began to question the validity of accelerated aging tests which relied on dry heat and a single temperature, pointing out that relative humidity affects the chemical processes which produce paper degradation and that the reactions which cause degradation have different [[Activation energy|activation energies]]. This led researchers like Baer and Lindström to advocate accelerated aging techniques using the Arrhenius equation and a realistic relative humidity.<ref name="Porck"/>
===Criticism=== Accelerated aging techniques, particularly those using the Arrhenius equation, have frequently been criticized in recent decades. While some researchers claim that the Arrhenius equation can be used to quantitatively predict the lifespan of tested papers,<ref name="Zou">Zou, X.; Uesaka, T; & Gurnagul, G. (1996). Predication of paper permanence by accelerated aging I. Kinetic analysis of the aging process. ''Cellulose 3'', 243-267.</ref> other researchers disagree. Many argue that this method cannot predict an exact lifespan for the tested papers, but that it can be used to rank papers by permanence.<ref name="Strofer">Strofer-Hua, E. (1990). Experimental measurement: Interpreting extrapolation and prediction by accelerated aging. ''Restaurator 11'', 254-266.</ref><ref name="Begin">Bégin, P. L. & Kaminska, E. (2002). Thermal accelerated ageing test method development. ''Restaurator 23'', 89-105.</ref> A few researchers claim that even such rankings can be deceptive, and that these types of accelerated aging tests can only be used to determine whether a particular treatment or paper quality has a positive or negative effect on the paper’s permanence.<ref name="Bansa 2002">Bansa, H. (2002). Accelerated aging of paper: Some ideas on its practical benefit. ''Restaurator 23'', 106-117.</ref>
There are several reasons for this skepticism. One argument is that entirely different chemical processes take place at higher temperatures than at lower temperatures, which means the accelerated aging process and natural aging process are not parallel.<ref name="Porck"/><ref name="Bansa 2002"/><ref name="Bansa 1989">Bansa, H. (1989). Artificial aging as a predictor of paper’s future useful life. ''The Abbey Newsletter Monograph Supplement 1''.</ref> Another is that paper is a “complex system”<ref name="Strofer"/> and the Arrhenius equation only applicable to elementary reactions. Other researchers criticize the ways in which deterioration is measured during these experiments. Some point out that there is no standard point at which a paper is considered unusable for library and archival purposes.<ref name="Bansa 1989"/> Others claim that the degree of correlation between macroscopic, mechanical properties of paper and molecular, chemical deterioration has not been convincingly proven.<ref name="Strofer"/><ref name="Calvini">Calvini, P. & Gorassini, A. (2006). On the rate of paper degradation: Lessons from the past. ''Restaurator 27'', 275-290.</ref>
In an effort to improve the quality of accelerated aging tests, some researchers have begun comparing materials which have undergone accelerated aging to materials which have undergone natural aging.<ref name=" Batterham ">[http://www.naa.gov.au/images/batterham-rai_tcm2-13043.pdf ] Batterham, I & Rai, R. (2008). A comparison of artificial ageing with 27 years of natural ageing. ''2008 AICCM Book, Paper and Photographic Materials Symposium'', 81-89.</ref> The Library of Congress, for instance, began a [[long-term experiment]] in 2000 to compare artificially aged materials to materials allowed to undergo natural aging for a hundred years.<ref name="LOC 2008">[https://www.loc.gov/preserv/rt/projects/100-yr_nat_aging.html], Library of Congress (2008). 100-year paper natural aging project. ''The Library of Congress: Preservation. '' Retrieved 8 August 2009.</ref>

{{distinguish|text=[[Acetobacterium]], a distinct group of organisms}}
'''Acetic acid bacteria''' (AAB) are a group of [[Gram-negative]] bacteria which [[Oxidation|oxidize]] [[sugar]]s or [[ethanol]] and produce [[acetic acid]] during [[Fermentation (food)|fermentation]].<ref name=Raspor2008>{{cite journal|author1=Raspor P |author2=Goranovic D |title=Biotechnological applications of acetic acid bacteria |journal=Critical Reviews in Biotechnology |volume=28 |issue=2 |date=2008 |pages=101–124 |doi=10.1080/07388550802046749 |pmid=18568850}}</ref> The acetic acid bacteria consist of 10 [[genus|genera]] in the family ''[[Acetobacteraceae]]''.<ref name=Raspor2008/> Several species of acetic acid bacteria are used in industry for production of certain foods and chemicals.<ref name=Raspor2008/>
==Characteristics== All acetic acid bacteria are rod-shaped and [[obligate aerobe]]s.<ref name=Raspor2008/>
==Occurrence== Acetic acid bacteria are airborne and are ubiquitous in nature. They are actively present in environments where ethanol is being formed as a result of fermentation of sugars. They can be isolated from the [[nectar (plant)|nectar]] of flowers and from damaged fruit. Other good sources are fresh apple [[cider]] and unpasteurized beer that has not been filter sterilized. In these liquids, they grow as a surface film due to their aerobic nature and active motility. [[Drosophilidae|Fruit flies]] or [[Turbatrix aceti|vinegar eels]] are considered as a common vector in propagating acetic acid bacteria.<ref>{{cite book|url=http://www.springerlink.com/content/978-88-470-0865-6#section=103531&page=1 |accessdate=28 May 2016 |title=Vinegars of the World |chapter=Chapter 5 |isbn=978-88-470-0865-6}}</ref>
==Suppression== The growth of ''Acetobacter'' in wine can be suppressed through effective sanitation, by complete exclusion of air from wine in storage, and by the use of moderate amounts of [[sulfur dioxide]] in the wine as a preservative.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.practicalwinery.com/janfeb09/page4.htm |accessdate=28 May 2016 |title=Sulfur Dioxide: Science behind this anti-microbial, anti-oxidant |website=Practical Winery & Vineyard Journal |date=February 2009 |page=4}}</ref>
==Metabolism== [[Vinegar]] is produced when acetic acid bacteria act on alcoholic beverages such as wine. They are used to perform specific oxidation reactions through processes called “oxidative fermentations”, that creates vinegar as a byproduct. In the biotechnological industry, these bacterias' oxidation mechanism is exploited to produce a number of compounds such as l-ascorbic acid, dihydroxyacetone, gluconic acid, and cellulose.<ref name="Mamlouk, D. 2013">Mamlouk, D. & Gullo, M. Acetic Acid Bacteria: Physiology and Carbon Sources Oxidation. Indian Journal of Microbiology 53, 377–384 (2013).</ref>
Besides food industry, some acetic acid bacterias are used as biocatalysts for the industrial production of compounds. They are used as the important biocatalysts for the development of eco-friendly fermentation processes as an alternative to the chemical synthesis.<ref name="Mamlouk, D. 2013"/>
Some genera, such as ''Acetobacter'', can oxidize ethanol to carbon dioxide and water using [[Krebs cycle]] enzymes. Other genera, such as ''Gluconobacter'', do not oxidize ethanol, as they do not have a full set of Krebs cycle enzymes.
As these bacteria produce acid, they are usually acid-tolerant, growing well below pH 5.0, although the pH optimum for growth is 5.4-6.3.
One species of ''Acetobacter'', ''[[Acetobacter xylinum]]'', is able to synthesize [[cellulose]],<ref>{{cite journal|url=https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC1275385/pdf/biochemj00918-0116.pdf?tool=pmcentrez |accessdate=28 May 2016 |title=Formation of cellulose by certain species of ''Acetobacter'' |journal=Biochem. J. |date=May 1951 |volume=48 |issue=5 |pages=618–621 |pmc=1275385 |doi=10.1042/bj0480618 |pmid=14838912}}</ref> something normally done only by plants.

Tun Senaja (niece of Temenggung Seri Maharaja) | issue = [[Mahmud Shah of Malacca|Mahmud Shah]] | royal house = | dynasty = | father = [[Mansur Shah of Malacca|Mansur Shah]] | birth_date = | birth_place = | death_date = 1488 | death_place = | date of burial = | place of burial = | religion = [[Sunni Islam]] }} '''Sultan Alauddin Riayat Shah ibni Almarhum Sultan Mansur Shah''' (died 1488) was a sultan of the [[Malacca Sultanate]] from 1477 to 1488.[https://books.google.com/books?id=krl1BgAAQBAJ&pg=PA85&dq=Sultan+Alauddin+Riayat+Syah+1477&hl=en&sa=X&ei=ysvcVLjLIciguQTp9oKYCg&ved=0CE8Q6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=Sultan%20Alauddin%20Riayat%20Syah%201477&f=false Museums, History and Culture in Malaysia, By Abu Talib Ahmad]{{Cite book | last = Cœdès | first = George | authorlink = Georges Coedès | title = The Indianized states of Southeast Asia | publisher = University of Hawaii Press | year = 1968 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=iDyJBFTdiwoC | isbn =9780824803681 }}{{rp|246}} He was famous for going undercover at night to personally check on the well-being of his people, as well as on the condition of his sultanate itself. On one of these nights he was even reported to have run after a thief himself. He was a very good and religious ruler and is renowned to be a fair king. But his position is envied by his brother, Raja Ahmad (the ruler of Pahang, a region under Malaccan rule), because Raja Ahmad believed that the rulership of Malacca was his right. Sultan Alauddin had many enemies, both within and outside of his court. He had a total of four children, two from each of his two wives, and this has led to his wives squabbling over the heirship to his throne. The sultan's second wife is from Indian Muslim descent. During this period, Sultan Alaudin has been facing problems with the ''mamak'' people, who were beginning to grow in power in comparison to Malays. His new advisor, Bendahara Seri Maharaja (equivalent to the modern-day prime minister) was also of ''mamak'' blood. After 11 years on the throne, Sultan Alauddin was reported in history to have died of mysterious causes. Other accounts suggest that he was poisoned in a conspiracy primarily involving Raja Ahmad, Bendahara Seri Maharaja and Tun Senaja, his second wife. His son, Raja Mahmud and his brother-in-law Raja Merlang (Tun Senaja's brother) was also thought to be involved. After his demise, the rulership went to Raja Mahmud, whom he fathered with his Tun Senaja, and denying Raja Munawar, Sultan Alaudin's firstborn son with his first wife Raja Fatimah, who was widely thought to be the true successor to the throne. In any case, the ''mamak'' bloodline finally gained control over the Malaccan Empire. However, it was not long before the Portuguese invasion came in 1511, the aftermath of which ended the Sultanate rule over the [[Malacca]]. Today, Sultan Alauddin Riayat Shah's tomb can be found situated in [[Pagoh]], [[Johor]].{{cite web|url=http://www.tourmalaysia.com/malaysia-tourism/muar-heritage-trails-sultan-alauddin-riayat-tomb-kampong-raja-pagoh/ |title=Muar Tourist Attraction: Sultan Alauddin Riayat Shah's Tomb Kampong Raja Pagoh |publisher=[[Joshua Project]] |accessdate=2014-09-16}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{S-start}} {{S-hou|House of Malacca||||1488}} {{S-reg|}} {{S-bef|before=[[Mansur Shah of Malacca|Mansur Shah]]}} {{S-ttl|title=[[Sultan of Malacca]]|years=1477–1488}} {{S-aft|after=[[Mahmud Shah of Malacca|Mahmud Shah]]}} {{end}} {{Authority control}} {{Malaysia-bio-stub}} {{Malaysia-royal-stub}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Alauddin Riayat Shah Of Malacca}} [[Category:1488 deaths]] [[Category:Sultans of Malacca]] [[Category:History of Malacca]] [[Category:15th-century monarchs in Asia]] [[Category:Deaths by poisoning]]

'''Ali II of Yejju''' (c. 1819 – c. 1866) was a [[Ras (title)|Ras]] of [[Begemder]] and [[Enderase]] (Regent) of the [[Emperor of Ethiopia]]. He was the son of [[Alula of Yejju]] (sometime governor of [[Damot]] and then of [[Gojjam]]) and [[Menen Liben Amede]] (later Empress of [[Ethiopia]] through her marriage to [[Yohannes III|Emperor Yohannes III]]) and nephew of [[Gugsa of Yejju]].
==Appointment as ruler== In July 1831, after the death of his cousin, [[Dori of Yejju|Ras Dori]], Ali was appointed Ruler of Begemder and Imperial Regent at the age of 12 in a meeting of the chief nobles of the [[Yejju Oromo|Yejju]] at the dynastic capital of [[Debre Tabor]].<ref>{{cite book |last= Abir|first= Mordechai |title= Ethiopia: The Era of the Princes; The Challenge of Islam and the Re-unification of the Christian Empire (1769-1855)|year= 1968|publisher= Longmans|location= London|page=38}}</ref> As Ali was a minor, a council of regents was appointed from these nobles. However, his mother, Menen, soon came to control this council and exerted much influence over political decisions for the next decade.<ref>{{cite book |last= Rubenson|first= Sven |title= King of Kings: Tewodros of Ethiopia|year= 1966|publisher= Haile Selassie I University|location= Addis Ababa|page = 22}}</ref>
Ras Ali was officially a [[Christian]] but his contemporaries doubted the sincerity of his faith and suspected that he was a secret [[Muslim]]. Some modern scholars consider him as indifferent to religion as he was to the problems of ruling his portion of Ethiopia, although Trimingham observes that he attempted to revive the cult of [[Ahmad Gragn]] by requiring pilgrimages to his tomb.<ref>J. Spencer Trimingham, ''Islam in Ethiopia'' (Oxford: Geoffrey Cumberlege for the University Press, 1952), p. 111</ref> In any case, the morale of the [[Ethiopian Church]] reached its lowest point in the 1840s and 1850s.
For much his reign Ras Ali was constantly at war, either putting down rebellions in his core territories, or defending his territory from rival lords. In one of these continual campaigns, Ras Ali II plundered the imperial capital, [[Gondar]], in 1838.<ref>Abir, ''Era of the Princes'', p. 111f</ref>
Ras Ali made [[Sahle Dengel of Ethiopia|Sahle Dengel]] Emperor in 1832, but the clergy of [[Azazo]] disapproved of the new Emperor's religious beliefs, and convinced Ras Ali to remove him. Sahle Dengel was sent to [[Zengaj]], and Ras Ali recalled [[Gebre Krestos of Ethiopia|Gebre Krestos]] from [[Mitraha Island|Mitraha]], an island in [[Lake Tana]], and restored him as Emperor. However, Gebre Krestos died after three months, and Sahle Dengel met with Ras Ali in the village of Tsagur where he convinced Ras Ali to restore him to the throne once again (October, 1832).<ref>{{cite book |last= Weld Blundell|first= H. |title= The Royal chronicle of Abyssinia, 1769-1840 |year= 1922|publisher= University Press|location= Cambridge|page = 489}}</ref>
==Marriage== Ras Ali married Hirut, the daughter of [[Dejazmach]] [[Wube Haile Maryam]], warlord of [[Semien province|Semien]] and of [[Tigray Province|Tigray]]; when he placed her in the church of [[Mahdere Maryam]] for her safety before the [[Battle of Debre Tabor]] (6 February 1842), his opponents violated the refuge of the church and kidnapped her. Their only daughter [[Tewabech Ali|Tewabech]] was married 1848 to Kassa Hailu of [[Qwara province|Qwara]], who in 1854 proclaimed himself a [[Negus]]. They had no surviving issue.
==End of reign== Although his reign was punctuated by recurrent rebellions, Ali managed to keep all of the major lords subject to his rule until the final years. Shiferaw Bekele asserts that "it is to his credit" that there were only two major wars while he was ''Ras Bewodded'': the Battle of Debre Tabor in 1842, and [[Tewodros II of Ethiopia|Kassa Hailu]]'s successful offensive in 1852/1853.<ref>Shiferaw Bekele, [http://www.persee.fr/web/revues/home/prescript/article/ethio_0066-2127_1990_num_15_1_951?_Prescripts_Search_isPortletOuvrage=false "Reflections on the Power Elite of the Wärä Seh Mäsfenate (1786-1853)" ''Annales d'Éthiopie''] 15 (1990), p. 161</ref>
Future events were foreshadowed in October, 1846, when Kassa Hailu defeated detachments of Empress Menen's army at two separate battles in [[Dembiya]]; at the time, ''Ras'' Ali was away in [[Gojjam]] attempting to subdue the province's warlord, [[Birru Goshu]], and unable to assist his mother. Kassa defeated the army of Empress Menen the following year on 18 June at [[Battle of Iloha|Iloha]], and took both Menen and her husband the former Emperor [[Yohannes III of Ethiopia|Yohannes III]] captive, forcing Ras Ali to negotiate their release. After three months, in return for making Kassa [[dejazmach]] over Dembiya, north of [[Lake Tana]], the Empress and her powerless husband were released.<ref>Rubenson, ''King of Kings'', pp. 37f</ref> Dejazmach Kassa later reconciled himself to ''Ras'' Ali in 1849, and Kassa remained loyal to Ali for the next three years.
However, the relationship between the two eventually deteriorated. Following a series of stunning victories by Kassa, Ali II was decisively defeated by his son-in-law ''Dejazmach'' Kassa (who later assumed the throne name of [[Tewodros II of Ethiopia|Tewodros II]]) in the [[Battle of Ayshal]] on 29 June 1853, and he lost both the regentship and his territories. At first Ali fled to safety at a local church, then a few days later fled to the territories of his kinsmen in [[Wollo]] province, where he disappeared to history. Sven Rubenson states that he advised Queen [[Worqitu of Wollo|Worqitu]] of the [[Wollo Oromo]] to avoid a major battle with Tewodros when the Emperor marched through Wollo on his campaign against [[Shewa]] in 1855.<ref>Rubenson, ''King of Kings'', p. 52.</ref> Both Proutky<ref>Chris Proutky, ''Empress Taytu and Menelik II: Ethiopia 1883-1910'' (Trenton: The Red Sea Press, 1986), p. 27n</ref> and Trimingham<ref>Trimingham, ''Islam'', p. 110</ref> give the date of 1866 for his death, without further details.

{{Merge |Constriction ring syndrome |date=March 2018 }} {{Infobox medical condition (new) | name = Amniotic band syndrome | synonyms = | image = Amniotic band hand.jpg | caption = A baby's hand affected by amniotic band syndrome | pronounce = | field = | symptoms = | complications = | onset = | duration = | types = | causes = | risks = | diagnosis = | differential = | prevention = | treatment = | medication = | prognosis = | frequency = | deaths = }}
'''Amniotic band constriction''' (also known as "amniotic band syndrome", "ADAM complex", "Amniotic band sequence", "Congenital constriction bands" and "Pseudoainhum"<ref name="Bolognia">{{cite book |author =Rapini, Ronald P. |author2 =Bolognia, Jean L. |author3 =Jorizzo, Joseph L. |title=Dermatology: 2-Volume Set |publisher=Mosby |location=St. Louis |year=2007 |pages= |isbn=1-4160-2999-0 |oclc= |doi= |accessdate=}}</ref>) is a [[congenital disorder]] caused by entrapment of fetal parts (usually a limb or digits) in fibrous amniotic bands while in utero.
==Signs and symptoms== The constriction of appendages by amniotic bands may result in:
# Constriction rings around the digits, arms and legs # Swelling of the extremities distal to the point of constriction ([[congenital lymphedema]]) # Amputation of digits, arms and legs ([[congenital amputation]])
A strong relationship between ABS and [[clubfoot]] (also called "talipes") exists. A 31.5% of associated clubfoot deformity and ABS can be correlated with 20% occurring [[bilateral symmetry|bilateral]]ly. Other abnormalities found with ABS include: [[clubhand]]s, [[cleft lip]], and/or [[cleft palate]], and [[hemangioma]].
Decreased fetal movement could be a sign of a serious problem which may include ABS. It is rare but possible for the membrane to become wrapped around the placenta or the neck of the baby in the womb causing strangulation and death.
==Cause== To explain the cause of ABS, there are two main theories.
The '''amniotic band''' theory is that ABS occurs due to a partial rupture of the [[amniotic sac]]. This rupture involves only the [[amnion]]; the [[chorion]] remains intact. Fibrous bands of the ruptured amnion float in the [[amniotic fluid]] and can encircle and trap some part of the fetus. Later, as the fetus grows but the bands do not, the bands become constricting. This constriction reduces blood circulation, hence causes congenital abnormalities. In some cases a complete "natural" [[congenital amputation|amputation]] of a digit(s) or limb may occur before birth or the digit(s) or limbs may be necrotic (dead) and require surgical amputation following birth.
The '''vascular disruption''' theory: Because the constricting mechanism of the amniotic band theory does not explain the high incidence of [[cleft palate]] and other forms of cleft defects occurring together with ABS, this co-occurrence suggests an "intrinsic" defect of the blood circulation.
==Diagnosis== [[File:Ultrasound Scan ND 008.jpg|thumb]] Amniotic band syndrome is often difficult to detect before birth as the individual strands are small and hard to see on ultrasound. Often the bands are detected indirectly because of the constrictions and swelling upon limbs, digits, etc. Misdiagnosis is also common, so if there are any signs of amniotic bands, further detailed ultrasound tests should be done to assess the severity. 3D ultrasound and MRI can be used for more detailed and accurate diagnosis of bands and the resulting damage/danger to the fetus. ==Prevention== Amniotic band syndrome is considered an accidental event and it does not appear to be genetic or hereditary, so the likelihood of it occurring in another pregnancy is remote. The cause of amnion tearing is unknown and as such there are no known preventative measures.
==Treatment== In rare cases, if diagnosed in utero, [[fetal surgery]] may be considered to save a limb which is in danger of amputation or other deformity. This typically would not be attempted if neither vital organs nor the [[umbilical cord]] were affected. This operation has been successfully performed on fetuses as young as 22 weeks.<ref name=abc20080608>{{Cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/stories/2008/06/08/2268374.htm |title=Surgeons save unborn baby's legs |publisher=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |work=News Online |date=2008-06-08}}</ref> The surgery took place at Melbourne's Monash Medical Centre in [[Australia]] and is believed to be the earliest surgery of its type, as surgeons usually hold off on operating until the woman is in week 28 of gestation.{{citation needed|date=July 2012}} There are also several facilities in the United States that have performed successful amniotic band release surgery.
Treatment usually occurs after birth and where plastic and reconstructive surgery is considered to treat the resulting deformity.<ref>{{cite journal |author =Gabos PG |title=Modified technique for the surgical treatment of congenital constriction bands of the arms and legs of infants and children |journal=Orthopedics |volume=29 |issue=5 |pages=401–4 |year=2006 |pmid=16729738 |doi=}}</ref> Plastic surgery ranges from simple to complex depending on the extent of the deformity. Physical and occupational therapy may be needed long term.
Prosthetics may help some ABS sufferers to live more functional lives. The price and complexity of these prosthetics vary dramatically, but advances in [[3-D printing]] have helped to increase the availability of artificial fingers while reducing their cost of production.<ref>{{Cite news |url=http://www.kuow.org/post/3-d-printer-brings-dexterity-children-no-fingers |title=3-D Printer Brings Dexterity To Children With No Fingers |work=News Online |date=2013-06-18}}</ref>
==Prognosis== [[File:Amniotic Band Syndrome 26 Year old Male.jpg|thumb|Amniotic Band Syndrome, 26-year-old Male]] The [[prognosis]] depends on the location and severity of the constricting bands. Every case is different and multiple bands may be entangled around the fetus.
Bands which wrap around fingers and toes can result in [[syndactyly]] or [[congenital amputation|amputation]]s of the digits. In other instances, bands can wrap around limbs causing restriction of movement resulting in clubbed feet. In more severe cases, the bands can constrict the limb causing decreased blood supply and amputation. Amniotic bands can also sometimes attach to the face or neck causing deformities such as cleft lip and palate. If the bands become wrapped around the head or umbilical cord it can be life-threatening for the fetus.
The number of cases of [[miscarriage]] that can be attributed to ABS is unknown, although it has been reported that it may be the cause of 178 in 10,000 miscarriages.
==Epidemiology== Amniotic banding affects approximately 1 in 1,200 live births. It is also believed to be the cause of 178 in 10,000 [[miscarriage]]s. Up to 50% of cases have other congenital anomalies including cleft lip, cleft palate, and clubfoot deformity. Hand and finger anomalies occur in up to 80%.
==People living with ABS== Among the more notable people living with ABS are:
* [[Sophie Wells]], British member Paralympics dressage team <ref>Sophie Wells website http://www.sophiewells.com/</ref> * [[Gina Casillas]], US volleyball player <ref>{{cite web|title=Superhands|url=http://www.superhands.us/pages/casillas.html|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160304023059/http://www.superhands.us/pages/casillas.html|archive-date=2016-03-04|access-date=2013-08-27|dead-url=no|df=}}</ref> * [[Ian T. Jamison]], US artist <ref>Single-handed art {{cite web|url=http://www.singlehandedart.com/the-artist |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-08-27 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130219113217/http://www.singlehandedart.com/the-artist |archivedate=2013-02-19 |df= }}</ref> * [[Anna Johannes]], US Paralympic swimmer<ref>'Despite setbacks, swimmer takes head-first approach to reaching Paralympic gold' http://www.local12.com/ara/hottopics/story/Despite-setbacks-swimmer-takes-head-first/VpNtHBpp0U2YTLDQu0TmSQ.cspx{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}</ref> * [[Jean-Jacques Machado]], 7th degree red-and-black belt in [[Brazilian Jiu-Jitsu]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bjjheroes.com/bjj-fighters/jean-jacques-machado-bjj-fighter-wiki|title=Jean Jacques Machado - BJJ Heroes|website=BJJ Heroes}}</ref> * [[Monica Price]], a case study of a young woman born with amniotic band syndrome <ref>Monica Price website http://specialneedsfamilyfun.com/family/monica.htm</ref> * [[Kingsley McGowan]], U.S. Men's Rugby Player <ref>{{cite web|url=http://usarugby.org/mens-eagles|title=Men's Eagles - USA Rugby National Teams|publisher=}}</ref> * [[Troy Fumagalli]], University of Wisconsin Football Player (2017 Cotton Bowl Offensive MVP) * [[Lyric Mariah Heard]] U.S. model<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/style/models-birth-defects-says-gave-purpose-185128379.html|author=Cindy Arboleda|accessdate=August 12, 2017|publisher=Yahoo|title=Model's birth defects, she says, 'gave me a purpose'}}</ref> * [[Shaquem Griffin]], Seattle Seahawks Football Player (2016 [[American Athletic Conference football individual awards#Defensive Player of the Year|AAC Defensive Player of the Year]])<ref>{{cite news|last1=Glock|first1=Allison|title=Central Florida's Shaquill and Shaquem Griffin have three hands and NFl dreams|url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/page/bodyissue2013griffins/central-florida-shaquill-shaquem-griffin-three-hands-nfl-dreams-espn-magazine|work=ESPN.com}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=Green|first1=Shannon|title=Shaquem, Shaquill Griffin shine for UCF, don't let disability hold them back|url=http://www.orlandosentinel.com/sports/ucf-knights/os-ucf-football-0909-20160908-story.html|work=Orlando Sentinel|date=September 8, 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Adelson|first1=Eric|title=Is the NFL next for one-handed Shaquem Griffin?|url=https://sports.yahoo.com/nfl-next-one-handed-shaquem-griffin-195159947.html|publisher=Yahoo Sports|date=August 17, 2017}}</ref> *[[Jennifer Bricker]], acrobat and aerialist <ref>http://abcnews.go.com/US/champion-gymnast-dominque-moceanus-secret-sister/story?id=16511330#.T9Pbi9VYv8E</ref>
